<body lang=EN-US link=blue vlink="#954F72" style='tab-interval:.5in'>

<div class=WordSection1>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:7.5pt;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:7.5pt;
margin-left:0in;line-height:30.0pt;mso-outline-level:1;background:white'><b><span
style='font-size:29.0pt;font-family:"inherit",serif;mso-fareast-font-family:
"Times New Roman";mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman";color:#333333;
mso-font-kerning:18.0pt'>Practical Machine Learning Course Project<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:7.5pt;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:7.5pt;
margin-left:0in;line-height:15.0pt;mso-outline-level:4;background:white'><b><i><span
style='font-size:13.0pt;font-family:"inherit",serif;mso-fareast-font-family:
"Times New Roman";mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman";color:#333333'>Mehul
Singh</span></i></b><b><span style='font-size:13.0pt;font-family:"inherit",serif;
mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman";
color:#333333'><o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:7.5pt;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:7.5pt;
margin-left:0in;line-height:15.0pt;mso-outline-level:4;background:white'><b><i><span
style='font-size:13.0pt;font-family:"inherit",serif;mso-fareast-font-family:
"Times New Roman";mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman";color:#333333'>Saturday,
February 18, 2017</span></i></b><b><span style='font-size:13.0pt;font-family:
"inherit",serif;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";mso-bidi-font-family:
"Times New Roman";color:#333333'><o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:7.5pt;line-height:normal;background:
white'><span style='font-size:10.5pt;font-family:"Helvetica",sans-serif;
mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman";
color:#333333'>(Background, Data and <span class=GramE>What</span> you should
submit sections are directly copied from course’s assignment page)<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:7.5pt;line-height:normal;background:
white'><b><span style='font-size:10.5pt;font-family:"Helvetica",sans-serif;
mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman";
color:#333333'>Background</span></b><span style='font-size:10.5pt;font-family:
"Helvetica",sans-serif;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";mso-bidi-font-family:
"Times New Roman";color:#333333'><o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:7.5pt;line-height:normal;background:
white'><span style='font-size:10.5pt;font-family:"Helvetica",sans-serif;
mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman";
color:#333333'>Using devices such as Jawbone Up, Nike <span class=SpellE>FuelBand</span>,
and Fitbit it is now possible to collect a large amount of data about personal
activity relatively inexpensively. These type of devices are part of the
quantified <span class=SpellE>self movement</span> - a group of enthusiasts who
take measurements about themselves regularly to improve their health, to find
patterns in their behavior, or because they are tech geeks. One thing that
people regularly do is quantify how much of a particular activity they do, but
they rarely quantify how well they do it. In this project, your goal will be to
use data from accelerometers on the belt, forearm, arm, and <span class=SpellE>dumbell</span>
of 6 participants. They were asked to perform barbell lifts correctly and
incorrectly in 5 different ways. More information is available from the website
here:&nbsp;<a href="http://groupware.les.inf.puc-rio.br/har"><span
style='color:#0088CC;text-decoration:none;text-underline:none'>http://groupware.les.inf.puc-rio.br/har</span></a>&nbsp;(see
the section on the Weight Lifting Exercise Dataset).<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:7.5pt;line-height:normal;background:
white'><b><span style='font-size:10.5pt;font-family:"Helvetica",sans-serif;
mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman";
color:#333333'>Data</span></b><span style='font-size:10.5pt;font-family:"Helvetica",sans-serif;
mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman";
color:#333333'><o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:7.5pt;line-height:normal;background:
white'><span style='font-size:10.5pt;font-family:"Helvetica",sans-serif;
mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman";
color:#333333'>The training data for this project are available here: [<a
href="https://d396qusza40orc.cloudfront.net/predmachlearn/pml-training.csv"><span
style='color:#0088CC;text-decoration:none;text-underline:none'>https://d396qusza40orc.cloudfront.net/predmachlearn/pml-training.csv</span></a>]<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:7.5pt;line-height:normal;background:
white'><span style='font-size:10.5pt;font-family:"Helvetica",sans-serif;
mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman";
color:#333333'>The test data are available here: [<a
href="https://d396qusza40orc.cloudfront.net/predmachlearn/pml-testing.csv"><span
style='color:#0088CC;text-decoration:none;text-underline:none'>https://d396qusza40orc.cloudfront.net/predmachlearn/pml-testing.csv</span></a>]<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:7.5pt;line-height:normal;background:
white'><span style='font-size:10.5pt;font-family:"Helvetica",sans-serif;
mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman";
color:#333333'>The data for this project come from this source: [<a
href="http://groupware.les.inf.puc-rio.br/har"><span style='color:#0088CC;
text-decoration:none;text-underline:none'>http://groupware.les.inf.puc-rio.br/har</span></a>].
If you use the document you create for this class for any purpose please cite
them as they have been very generous in allowing their data to be used for this
kind of assignment.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:7.5pt;line-height:normal;background:
white'><b><span style='font-size:10.5pt;font-family:"Helvetica",sans-serif;
mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman";
color:#333333'>What you should submit</span></b><span style='font-size:10.5pt;
font-family:"Helvetica",sans-serif;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";
mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman";color:#333333'><o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:7.5pt;line-height:normal;background:
white'><span style='font-size:10.5pt;font-family:"Helvetica",sans-serif;
mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman";
color:#333333'>The goal of your project is to predict the manner in which they
did the exercise. This is the “<span class=SpellE>classe</span>” variable in
the training set. You may use any of the other variables to predict with. You
should create a report describing how you built your model, how you used cross
validation, what you think the expected out of sample error is, and why you made
the choices you did. You will also use your prediction model to predict 20
different test cases.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:7.5pt;line-height:normal;background:
white'><span style='font-size:10.5pt;font-family:"Helvetica",sans-serif;
mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman";
color:#333333'>Your submission should consist of a link to a <span
class=SpellE>Github</span> repo with your R markdown and compiled HTML file
describing your analysis. Please constrain the text of the <span class=SpellE>writeup</span>
to &lt; 2000 words and the number of figures to be less than 5. It will make it
easier for the graders if you submit a repo with a <span class=SpellE>gh</span>-pages
branch so the HTML page can be viewed online (and you always want to make it
easy on graders :-).<br>
You should also apply your machine learning algorithm to the 20 test cases
available in the test data above. Please submit your predictions in appropriate
format to the programming assignment for automated grading. See the programming
assignment for additional details.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<h3 style='margin-top:7.5pt;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:7.5pt;margin-left:
0in;line-height:30.0pt;background:white'><span style='font-size:18.5pt;
font-family:"Helvetica",sans-serif;color:#333333'>Preliminary Work<o:p></o:p></span></h3>

<p style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:7.5pt;margin-left:0in;
background:white;font-variant-ligatures: normal;font-variant-caps: normal;
orphans: 2;text-align:start;widows: 2;-webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px;
word-spacing:0px'><span class=SpellE><strong><span style='font-size:10.5pt;
font-family:"Helvetica",sans-serif;color:#333333'>Reproduceability</span></strong></span><span
style='font-size:10.5pt;font-family:"Helvetica",sans-serif;color:#333333'><o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:7.5pt;margin-left:0in;
background:white;font-variant-ligatures: normal;font-variant-caps: normal;
orphans: 2;text-align:start;widows: 2;-webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px;
word-spacing:0px'><span style='font-size:10.5pt;font-family:"Helvetica",sans-serif;
color:#333333'>An overall pseudo-random number generator seed was set at 1234
for all code. In order to reproduce the results below, the same seed should be
used.<br>
Different packages were downloaded and installed, such as caret and <span
class=SpellE>randomForest</span>. These should also be installed in order to
reproduce the results below (please see code below for ways and syntax to do
so).<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:7.5pt;margin-left:0in;
background:white;font-variant-ligatures: normal;font-variant-caps: normal;
orphans: 2;text-align:start;widows: 2;-webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px;
word-spacing:0px'><strong><span style='font-size:10.5pt;font-family:"Helvetica",sans-serif;
color:#333333'>How the model was built</span></strong><span style='font-size:
10.5pt;font-family:"Helvetica",sans-serif;color:#333333'><o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:7.5pt;margin-left:0in;
background:white;font-variant-ligatures: normal;font-variant-caps: normal;
orphans: 2;text-align:start;widows: 2;-webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px;
word-spacing:0px'><span style='font-size:10.5pt;font-family:"Helvetica",sans-serif;
color:#333333'>Our outcome variable is <span class=SpellE>classe</span>, a
factor variable with 5 levels. For this data set, “participants were asked to
perform one set of 10 repetitions of the Unilateral Dumbbell Biceps Curl in 5
different fashions:<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal>- <span class=GramE>exactly</span> according to the
specification (Class A)<o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal>- throwing the elbows to the front (Class B)<o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal>- lifting the dumbbell only halfway (Class C)<o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal>- lowering the dumbbell only halfway (Class D)<o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal>- throwing the hips to the front (Class E)</p>

<p style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:7.5pt;margin-left:0in;
background:white'><span style='font-size:10.5pt;font-family:"Helvetica",sans-serif;
color:#333333'>Class A corresponds to the specified execution of the exercise,
while the other 4 classes correspond to common mistakes.&quot; [1<span
class=GramE>]</span><br>
Prediction evaluations will be based on maximizing the accuracy and minimizing
the out-of-sample error. All other available variables after cleaning will be
used for prediction.<br>
Two models will be tested using decision tree and random forest algorithms. The
model with the highest accuracy will be chosen as our final model.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:7.5pt;margin-left:0in;
background:white;font-variant-ligatures: normal;font-variant-caps: normal;
orphans: 2;text-align:start;widows: 2;-webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px;
word-spacing:0px'><strong><span style='font-size:10.5pt;font-family:"Helvetica",sans-serif;
color:#333333'>Cross-validation</span></strong><span style='font-size:10.5pt;
font-family:"Helvetica",sans-serif;color:#333333'><o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:7.5pt;margin-left:0in;
background:white;font-variant-ligatures: normal;font-variant-caps: normal;
orphans: 2;text-align:start;widows: 2;-webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px;
word-spacing:0px'><span style='font-size:10.5pt;font-family:"Helvetica",sans-serif;
color:#333333'>Cross-validation will be performed by subsampling our training
data set randomly without replacement into 2 subsamples: <span class=SpellE>subTraining</span>
data (75% of the original Training data set) and <span class=SpellE>subTesting</span>
data (25%). Our models will be fitted on the <span class=SpellE>subTraining</span>
data set, and tested on the <span class=SpellE>subTesting</span> data. Once the
most accurate model is <span class=SpellE>choosen</span>, it will be tested on
the original Testing data set.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:7.5pt;margin-left:0in;
background:white;font-variant-ligatures: normal;font-variant-caps: normal;
orphans: 2;text-align:start;widows: 2;-webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px;
word-spacing:0px'><strong><span style='font-size:10.5pt;font-family:"Helvetica",sans-serif;
color:#333333'>Expected out-of-sample error</span></strong><span
style='font-size:10.5pt;font-family:"Helvetica",sans-serif;color:#333333'><o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:7.5pt;margin-left:0in;
background:white;font-variant-ligatures: normal;font-variant-caps: normal;
orphans: 2;text-align:start;widows: 2;-webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px;
word-spacing:0px'><span style='font-size:10.5pt;font-family:"Helvetica",sans-serif;
color:#333333'>The expected out-of-sample error will correspond to the
quantity: 1-accuracy in the cross-validation data. Accuracy is the proportion
of correct classified observation over the total sample in the <span
class=SpellE>subTesting</span> data set. Expected accuracy is the expected
accuracy in the out-of-sample data set (i.e.&nbsp;original testing data set).
Thus, the expected value of the out-of-sample error will correspond to the
expected number of <span class=SpellE>missclassified</span> observations/total
observations in the Test data set, which is the quantity: 1-accuracy found from
the cross-validation data set.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:7.5pt;margin-left:0in;
background:white;font-variant-ligatures: normal;font-variant-caps: normal;
orphans: 2;text-align:start;widows: 2;-webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px;
word-spacing:0px'><strong><span style='font-size:10.5pt;font-family:"Helvetica",sans-serif;
color:#333333'>Reasons for my choices</span></strong><span style='font-size:
10.5pt;font-family:"Helvetica",sans-serif;color:#333333'><o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:7.5pt;margin-left:0in;
background:white;font-variant-ligatures: normal;font-variant-caps: normal;
orphans: 2;text-align:start;widows: 2;-webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px;
word-spacing:0px'><span style='font-size:10.5pt;font-family:"Helvetica",sans-serif;
color:#333333'>Our outcome variable “<span class=SpellE>classe</span>” is an
unordered factor variable. Thus, we can choose our error type as 1-accuracy. We
have a large sample size with N= 19622 in the Training data set. This allow us
to divide our Training sample into <span class=SpellE>subTraining</span> and <span
class=SpellE>subTesting</span> to allow cross-validation. Features with all
missing values will be discarded as well as features that are irrelevant. All
other features will be kept as relevant variables.<br>
Decision tree and random forest algorithms are known for their ability of
detecting the features that are important for classification [2]. Feature
selection is inherent, so it is not so necessary at the data preparation phase.
Thus, there won’t be any feature selection section in this report.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<h3 style='margin-top:7.5pt;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:7.5pt;margin-left:
0in;line-height:30.0pt;background:white'><span style='font-size:18.5pt;
font-family:"Helvetica",sans-serif;color:#333333'>Code and Results<o:p></o:p></span></h3>

orphans: 2;text-align:start;widows: 2;-webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px;
word-spacing:0px'><strong><span style='font-size:10.5pt;font-family:"Helvetica",sans-serif;
color:#333333'>Packages, Libraries, Seed</span></strong><span style='font-size:
10.5pt;font-family:"Helvetica",sans-serif;color:#333333'><o:p></o:p></span></p>

color:#333333'>As expected, Random Forest algorithm performed better than
Decision Trees.<br>
Accuracy for Random Forest model was 0.995 (95% CI: (0.993, 0.997)) compared to
0.739 (95% CI: (0.727, 0.752)) for Decision Tree model.<span
class=apple-converted-space>&nbsp;</span><strong><span style='font-family:"Helvetica",sans-serif'>The
random Forest model is chosen</span></strong>. The accuracy of the model is
0.995. The expected out-of-sample error is estimated at 0.005, or<span
class=apple-converted-space>&nbsp;</span><strong><span style='font-family:"Helvetica",sans-serif'>0.5%</span></strong>.
The expected out-of-sample error is calculated as 1 - accuracy for predictions
made against the cross-validation set. Our Test data set comprises 20 cases.
With an accuracy above 99% on our cross-validation data, we can expect that
very few, or none, of the test samples will be misclassified.<o:p></o:p></span></p>
